back.content: Maximum speed limit sign: Indicates the maximum speed allowed on the road in kilometers per hour (km/h).

front.content: What are the main types of roads in Spain?

back.content:
• Interurban roads (highways or 'carreteras')
• Urban roads
• Crossings

front.content: Where are 'carreteras' (highways) located?

back.content: • Outside urban areas (interurban)

front.content: What are the three main types of interurban roads in Spain?

back.content:
• Autopistas (Motorways)
• Autovías (Dual Carriageways)
• Conventional Highways

front.content: What is the minimum speed capability required for vehicles on autopistas and autovías?

back.content: • 60 km/h

front.content: Key features of autopistas (motorways) in Spain?

back.content:
• Separate carriageways
• Median strips
• No level crossings
• Limited access
• Usually tolled

front.content: Key features of autovías (dual carriageways) in Spain?

back.content:
• Separate carriageways
• Median strips
• Some level crossings possible
• Less restricted access
• Always free

front.content: What is a conventional highway in Spain?

back.content:
• Any other interurban road
• No special limitations
• Single or dual carriageways
• May have level crossings

front.content: Which vehicles/users are NOT allowed on autopistas and autovías?

back.content:
• Bicycles
• Mopeds
• Vehicles for people with reduced mobility
• Pedestrians
• Animals

front.content: Are motorcycles allowed on autopistas and autovías?

back.content: • Yes, motorcycles are allowed on autopistas and autovías

front.content: Can cyclists use the hard shoulder on autopistas and autovías?

back.content:
• Cyclists over 14 years old may use the hard shoulder
• Only when not prohibited by signage
• Only on certain sections where it's explicitly allowed

front.content: What vehicles can use lanes reserved for buses?

back.content:
• Public transport vehicles
• Taxis (when 'TAXI' is visible on the signage)
• Other vehicles may use discontinuous sections for specific maneuvers (not for parking, stopping, changing direction, or overtaking)

front.content: What are the rules for High Occupancy Vehicle (HOV) lanes?

back.content:
• Can be permanent or temporary
• For vehicles transporting people with Maximum Authorized Mass (MMA) ≤ 3.5 tonnes
• Must have minimum number of occupants as specified for that section
• Also usable by:
  - Buses
  - Motorcycles
  - Cars with handicapped signs

front.content: What are the rules for driving in reversible lanes?

back.content:
• Identified by double broken line markings
• Headlights must be used at all times (day and night)
• Driving in the left reversible lane is forbidden
• Direction of traffic can change based on traffic flow needs

front.content: What are the three types of circumstantial lanes in Spain?

back.content:
• Revertive lanes
• Additional lanes
• Contraflow lanes

front.content: What are the general rules for circumstantial lanes in Spain?

back.content:
• Headlights must be used (day and night)
• Speed limits may apply (typically between 60-80 km/h, but can vary)
• Drivers must not cross or change the line formed by traffic barriers
• Specific rules may apply to each type of circumstantial lane

front.content: What are the rules for contraflow lanes in Spain?

back.content:
• Designed to increase traffic flow
• Only motorcycles and vehicles without trailers are permitted
• Headlights must be used
• Speed limits typically between 60-80 km/h (may vary)
• Follow the same rules as additional circumstantial lanes

front.content: What are the rules for using the hard shoulder (arcén) in Spain?

back.content:
• Hard shoulders are generally not for driving
• Exceptions for specific vehicles:
  - Bicycles, mopeds, and slow-moving vehicles must use the hard shoulder if present and passable
  - Agricultural vehicles and machinery
  - Road maintenance vehicles
• Emergency use:
  - For breakdowns or emergencies
  - To avoid accidents
• Temporary use when directed by traffic signs or police

front.content: Which vehicles must use the hard shoulder in Spain when it's present and passable?

back.content:
• Bicycles
• Mopeds
• Slow-moving vehicles (e.g., animal-drawn vehicles)
• Agricultural vehicles and machinery

front.content: What are the speed limits (km/h) on motorways and dual carriageways in Spain for different vehicle types?

back.content:
• Cars, motorcycles, motorhomes ≤3.5t, pickups: 60-120
• Buses and adapted mixed vehicles: 60-100
• Trucks, vans, motorhomes >3.5t, articulated vehicles (e.g., with trailers): 60-90

front.content: What are the speed limits (km/h) on conventional highways and single carriageway roads in Spain for different vehicle types?

back.content:
• Cars, motorcycles, motorhomes ≤3.5t, pickups: 45-90
• Buses and adapted mixed vehicles: 45-90
• Trucks, vans, motorhomes >3.5t, articulated vehicles (e.g., with trailers): 40-80

front.content: What are the speed limits (km/h) on different types of urban roads in Spain?

back.content:
• Roads with a single lane and sidewalk: 20
• Roads with one lane per direction: 30
• Roads with 2 or more lanes per direction: 50
• Urban sections of highways/motorways: 80 (unless otherwise indicated)

front.content: What are the speed limits (km/h) for special vehicles in Spain?

back.content:
• Tractors and vehicles without brake lights: 25
• Special vehicles capable of > 60 km/h: 70
• Other special vehicles: 40
• Quadricycles and three-wheeled vehicles: 70
• Cycles and mopeds: 45

front.content: What are the speed limit reductions for certain vehicles in Spain?

back.content:
• Vehicles carrying children or dangerous goods: -10 km/h from the generic maximum speed
• Motorcycles, three-wheeled vehicles, and mopeds when towing: -10% from their maximum speed limit
